sen.j: 高橋虫麻呂（たかはしのむしまろ、生没年不詳）は、奈良時代の万葉歌人。
sen.e: TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro (dates of birth and death unknown) was a contributor to Manyoshu in the Nara Period.
TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro (dates of birth and death unknown) was a contributor to Manyoshu during the Nara Period.
TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro (year of birth and death unknown) was a contributor to Manyoshu during the Nara Period.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Muraji.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Muraji.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Muraji.
His status by birth is unknown.

His status by birth is unknown.

sen.j: 「万葉集」に34首の作品が入集し、そのうち長歌が14首・旋頭歌が1首である。
sen.e: He contributed 34 poems to "Manyoshu" (the oldest anthology of tanka) including 14 choka (long poem) and a Sedoka (head-repeated poem).
He contributed 34 poems to "Manyoshu" (the oldest anthology of tanka) including 14 choka (long poem) and a Sedoka (a poem where the head is repeated).
He contributed 34 poems to "Manyoshu" (the oldest anthology of tanka) including 14 choka (long poem) and a Sedoka (a poem where the head is repeated).

sen.j: 巻6の2首目からは「虫麻呂の歌（＝高橋連虫麻呂歌集）の中に出ず」としてのせている（巻6の1首目は笠金村の歌）。
sen.e: The second poem of Volume Six and subsequent ones are indicated that they are "not in the poems of Mushimaro (TAKAHASHI no Muraji Mushimaro's collection of poetry)" (The first poem of Volume Six is KASA no Kanemura's).

The second poem of Volume Six and subsequent poems are indicated as "not in the poems of Mushimaro (TAKAHASHI no Muraji Mushimaro's collection of poetry)" (The first poem of Volume Six is KASA no Kanemura's).

The second poem of Volume Six and subsequent poems are indicated as 'not in the poems of Mushimaro (TAKAHASHI no Muraji Mushimaro's collection of poetry)' (The first poem of Volume Six is KASA no Kanemura's).

sen.j: 719年（養老3年）前後、藤原宇合が常陸守であった頃に宇合の下僚となり、以後宇合の庇護を受けたという。
sen.e: At some point around 719, he became a subordinate of FUJIWARA no Umakai who was then Hitachi no kami (governor of Hitachi Province) and thereafter Mushimaro was under Umakai's patronage.
At some point around 719, he became a subordinate of FUJIWARA no Umakai who was then Hitachi no kami (governor of Hitachi Province) and thereafter Mushimaro was under Umakai's patronage.
At some point around 719, he became a subordinate of FUJIWARA no Umakai who was then Hitachi no kami (governor of Hitachi Province) and thereafter Mushimaro was under Umakai's patronage.

sen.j: 下総国真間（現在の千葉県市川市）の手児奈（てこな）の歌や、摂津国葦屋（現在の兵庫県芦屋市）の菟原処女（うないおとめ）の歌など、地方の伝説や人事を詠んだ歌が多い。
sen.e: He made many poems on local legends and personnel affairs such as a poem on the Maiden Tegona in Mama in Shimousa Province (present-day Ichikawa City, Chiba Prefecture) and a poem on Unai otome (the Maiden Unai) in Ashinoya in Settsu Province (present-day Ashiya City, Hyogo Prefecture).

He made many poems on local legends and personal affairs such as a poem about the Maiden Tegona in Mama in Shimousa Province (present-day Ichikawa City, Chiba Prefecture) and a poem about Unai otome (the Maiden Unai) from Ashinoya in Settsu Province (present-day Ashiya City, Hyogo Prefecture).

He made many poems on local legends and personal affairs such as a poem about the Maiden Tekona in Mama in Shimousa Province (present-day Ichikawa City, Chiba Prefecture) and a poem about Unai otome (the Maiden Unai) from Ashinoya in Settsu Province (present-day Ashiya City, Hyogo Prefecture).

sen.j: 虫麻呂が歌に詠んだ地域は、常陸国から駿河国にかけての東国と、摂津国・河内国・京都などである。
sen.e: Mushimaro's poems cover the area in the eastern part of Japan from Hitachi to Suruga Provinces as well as the western part of the country such as Settsu, Kawachi, and Kyoto.
Mushimaro's poems cover the areas in the eastern part of Japan from Hitachi to Suruga Provinces as well as the western part of the country such as Settsu, Kawachi, and Kyoto.
Mushimaro's poems cover the areas in the eastern part of Japan from Hitachi to Suruga Provinces as well as the western part of the country such as Settsu, Kawachi, and Kyoto.
